page.title: 06HOUSES IN THEDDINGWORTH
page.content: The A427 road forms the main street along which most of the housing has developed. The village consists of a Church, a Chapel, a Village Hall, a Pub, Shop/Post Office, 3 farms on the main street and a further 75 houses, two thirds being owner occupied. Most houses are built of red brick with slated roofs. A quarter have blue brick patterning, typical of this area. One cottage has some mud walls; one is half timbered, wattle and daub, with a thatched roof. One terrace is of brick with pebble exterior. The Church is also an exception being built of stone. One house survives from C15 and 6 are C17. Eight were built between the early C19 and 1837. But most of the dwellings are Victorian and Edwardian. Only 20 houses have been built since World War Two.
